application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Digital Phased Arrays: Challenges and Opportunities

div.p: Digital beamforming (DBF) has long been her- alded as the next frontier in phased array technology, and not without reason. The digitization of transmit and receive signals at the element level opens the door to new processing and beamforming schemes and promises to deliver maximum flexibility and unprecedented dynamic range in large systems. However, it is not without inherent technological risks and practical challenges associated with the amount of data to process and the use of less sophisticated transceivers. This paper provides broad overviews of several interrelated aspects of the resulting DBF trade spaces for these systems. In particular, emerging concepts are highlighted for the roles and interconnection of distributed beamforming/processing for fixed and adaptive beamforming. These are then related to digital array calibration mechanisms that can potentially reduce the need for data-and processing-intensive beamforming algorithms.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION TO DIGITAL PHASED ARRAYS
div.p: Phased array technology has evolved since the early 1950s to become a cornerstone of modern remote sensing, communication, and electronic warfare equipment [1]- [3]. In phased array systems, each antenna element is driven by circuitry that approximates relative time delays between antennas selected to steer toward a particular direction relative to the array face [4]. A beam is produced upon signal summation using array-level electronics on receive (Rx) or through radiation on transmit (Tx). The traditional phased array hardware implementation is shown in Fig. 1(a). This architecture may have active, solid-state front-end electronics (as depicted) or passive splitting/combining and element-level electronics; in either case, the electronics are primarily analog.

Modern "digitized subarray" phased arrays with multiple transceivers [Fig. 1(b)] are providing increasing functionality and performance at reduced cost, size, and weight compared to their predecessors [5]. This has been accompanied by advances in efficient front-end circuitry, improvements in packaging and integration, and an increased role of digital electronics closer to the aperture itself [6]- [8]. In this modern architecture, Tx/Rx beamforming is accomplished with analog combiner networks (usually passive) and phase shifters within each subarray to approximate true time delays. Digital transceivers drive the combined input/output (I/O) signals of each subarray, in turn connecting to digital beamformers that operate at the subarray level. Digitization of multiple subarray channels enables adaptive beamforming [9], [10], space-time adaptive processing (STAP) [11], and multiple concurrent functions, an important requirement for future systems like the multifunction phased array radar (MPAR) [12]. To form P simultaneous beams in arbitrary directions, the phase shifters and front-end analog beamformers must be instantiated P times. 1 Arrays with analog beamforming are inherently constrained to the beamforming scheme imposed by the exact configuration of front-end beamforming electronics.

The most generically flexible phased array architecture would feature digitization and control of both the transmitted and received signals at each antenna element, along with the ability to cover wide bandwidths. Such a system is depicted in Fig. 1(c). Because the element-level processing and subsequent beamforming is digital, it can be reconfigured and optimized for different applications. Ideally, this can be done without altering the front-end analog electronics and packaging. A fully digital array may have a digital-to-analog converter (DAC) and a waveform generator on each element [e.g., direct digital synthesizer (DDS), as depicted in the figure]. This provides inherent flexibility for new modes of operation beyond that of traditional beamforming, where the same "desired" signal is transmitted and/or received on each element. In summary and as further motivation for this technology, the primary benefits of element-level digitization include:

• simultaneous Rx (and even Tx) beams and dynamic digital subarray allocation (Section II); • adaptive digital beamforming (ADBF) with degrees of freedom (DOFs) extending to the element level [14] (Section III); • enhanced calibration capabilities, with the potential for ultralow sidelobes and wideband equalization [15], [16] (Section IV); • multiple-input-multiple-output (MIMO) radar and communication as well as reconfigurable Tx subapertures with independent waveforms [17]; • dynamic range (DR) improvements on the order of 10 log 10 ðNÞ dB with N transceivers, with some metrics limited by correlation of spurious products [6], [18], [19].

div.head: A. Paper Overview
div.p: With these benefits in mind, Section I-B highlights several past examples of these systems, followed by Section I-C that summarizes more recent trends. The remainder of the paper then provides a broad overview of ongoing challenges as well as emerging research opportunities to improve the underlying design trade spaces associated with the first three bulleted items above. Section II provides a basic DBF framework to facilitate a discussion on these topics then highlights architectures for basic DBF implementation. Section III discusses ADBF and means by which its processing requirements may be reduced. Section IV then presents calibrationspecific challenges as well as techniques that leverage element-level control and digitization to help address them. A wideband null-steering example is presented in Section V that illustrates how the underlying I/O, processing, and calibration trade spaces are all interconnected in the design of these modern systems. Finally, Section VI provides concluding remarks.

div.head: B. Past Examples of Digital Arrays
div.p: Several element-level digital arrays have been developed in recent decades. While details on large-scale, operational digital arrays have not been published in the open literature, the CEAFAR in Australia and the EL/M-2248 MF-STAR in Israel have both been described in press releases as being "fully digital" [20], [21]. The FlexDAR testbed, currently under development in the United States by the Office of Naval Research (ONR), is also a fully digital array [22]. There are several smaller element-level digital testbeds that have been reported in recent years. Many of these systems were developed to explore or illustrate the potential benefits listed above.

In the 1980-1990s, a few narrowband (few megahertz at most) fully digital testbeds appeared for Rx [16], [23], [24] and Tx [25] demonstrations, ADBF [26], and element-level calibration [27]. These early developments are well summarized in [15]. The team in [28] later demonstrated the digitization of hundreds of channels for precision beamforming on a conformal array. At the time, card-or rack-based commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) components were becoming available for digitization and processing, leading to a program at ONR with Lincoln Laboratory that developed a 96-element array with offline element-level equalization [29] and subsequent DBF. In 2003, Air Force Research Laboratory (AFRL), Lincoln Laboratory, and Lockheed Martin developed a 16-element S-band demonstrator [30] with two intermediate frequency (IF) down-conversion stages supporting narrowband (10 MHz) operation or stretch processing over 500 MHz, again with offline DBF. In 2003, the German Aerospace Center developed a 5 Â 5 Rx-only array for satellite communications featuring integration of the radio-frequency (RF) front-end and first IF stage on the patch antenna panel itself; small digital modules behind this panel performed digitization and processing [31].

The type of panel-level integration exhibited in these demonstrators was becoming common at the time for front-end array electronics [34], [35], motivating the additional integration of COTS transceivers and digitizers. The Army Digital Array Radar (DAR) project, funded by the U.S. Army (CERDEC) as a collaboration between industry and academia from ca. 2007-2011, resulted in the system testbed shown in Fig. 2 and detailed in [32]. This 16-element S-band system featured panel-level integration of direct-conversion transceivers, COTS DACs and analogto-digital converters (ADCs), and field-programmable gate arrays (FPGAs) for real-time beamforming of a single 20-MHz beam on both Tx and Rx. The X-band array described in [36] for UAV sense-and-avoid applications featured a similar combination of highly integrated RF front-ends with colocated digitizing electronics. There are recent reports of similar efforts in China [37], [38] and Norway [39]. The University of Oklahoma is developing an 8 Â 8 element line-replaceable unit (LRU) for an alldigital polarimetric phased array for MPAR-like applications that has, per element, two 10-W T/R modules driven by a two-channel direct-conversion transceiver with integrated ADCs, DACs, and digital filtering on a single chip. It is, in a sense, a technological successor to the Army DAR.

During the late 2000s, the ONR was developing a larger digital array radar (DAR) with an associated Affordable Common Radar Architecture (ACRA) effort [40], focusing in part on maturing open architecture concepts [8], [41] for handling data and control while forming multiple simultaneous beams in real time using FPGAs [42]. AFRL's wideband transformational elementlevel array (TELA) testbed utilizes digitization down to the element level and/or true time delay MMICs for wideband operation [43]. Other wideband benchtop testbeds have been reported in [44] and [45].

Numerous other highly digital demonstrators have appeared in support of research into advanced radar processing functions, such as the element-level MIMO testbed in [46]. The authors of [6] in this issue are developing digital testbeds supporting their research. As early as 1996 [47], several testbeds with element-level digitization have been developed to explore the practical aspects of DBF for commercial wireless, more recently including MIMO capabilities [48]. There are also several digitized subarray systems with a large number of channels that are helping inform the design choices for future fully digital arrays with similar packaging and processing challenges. The synthetic aperture radar (SAR) arrays in [49] and [50] have a large number of digitized subarrays. The work in [51]- [53] were precursors to the square kilometer array (radio astronomy), which will utilize faster and more efficient application-specific integrated circuits (ASICs) for front-end processing and aggregation of roughly 2.5 Pb/s of data [54]. Overall, these demonstrators and systems have all navigated and informed the underlying trade spaces highlighted in the rest of this paper.

div.head: C. Recent Trends
div.p: Unlike the Army DAR and similar systems above, many of these DBF prototypes used larger rack-and card-based solutions for higher DR transceivers and digitizers with higher sample rates [55]. For fully digital arrays, this approach scales poorly to larger and higher frequency arrays because of size constraints. Developments like that in [56] at the AFRL with integrated SiGe electronics more closely resemble the integration needed for future systems, but they have not yet been openly demonstrated in large arrays. The current DARPA Arrays at Commercial Timescales (ACT) program is seeking to close this gap for a wide variety of applications.

As digital beamforming (DBF) technologies continue to evolve [57] there has also been significant interest in lowering the cost of radar and phased array components in order to open up new application spaces (e.g., weather radar). Because system-level DR scales with the number of elements, digital arrays may be able to use lower cost/ complexity transceivers than their traditional array counterparts. Thus, as evidenced by the examples below, the path to digitization at every element in large arrays involves the use of increasingly integrated digital transceivers. Higher levels of RF integration are enabled by lowering the number of frequency conversion stages, eliminating the need for off-chip components and filters.

Despite the general trend of decreasing relative costs of digital hardware [58], there remain potential barriers to the widespread adoption of fully digital array technologies. For example, while traditional arrays typically have on the order of 32 b of control per element, the highly integrated transceivers for potential use in digital arrays have hundreds or even thousands. This leads to complex and highly application-and hardware-dependent control schemes. the original DAR demonstrator [32] (middle), its newer integrated transceiver panel (left), and dual polarization (8 Â 1) testbed [33] (right). The block diagram shows the interconnection of highly integrated transceivers, front-end electronics, and a basic DBF in individual panels.
This article has been accepted for inclusion in a future issue of this journal. Content is final as presented, with the exception of pagination.

There are more general practical challenges surrounding the performance, packaging, cost, and synchronization/ calibration of these potentially error-prone transceivers that must be addressed. A more obvious challenge is the sheer amount of data that must be ingested and processed by an array with ADCs at each of potentially thousands of elements. These challenges lead to the trade spaces explored in the remainder of this paper.

div.head: II. DBF TRADE SPACES AND ARCHITECTURES
div.p: The generic DBF process can be described as a frequencydependent linear combination of the element signals, ultimately reducing a large amount of data to a smaller number of data streams. The complex baseband equivalent representation of the Rx digital signal from the mth of M elements in an array can be described as
div.formula: X m ð!Þ ¼ F m ð!; ; ÞG m ð!Þ(1)
div.p: for an incident impulse from an angle pair ð; Þ; Tx operation is similar. 2 The active electronics gain G m ð!Þ cascades with the embedded element pattern F m ð!; ; Þ of the mth antenna. This pattern includes all mutual coupling, finite array, and platform-related effects [4]. An important example is that of a large planar array, where most elements are several rows from the edge of the array and patterns can be approximated as
div.formula: F m ð!; ; Þ % F 0 ð!; ; Þe jk 0 ûð;ÞÁ½r m Àr 0 (2)
div.p: where F 0 is the pattern of the element at location r 0 ; r m is mth element location, ûð; Þ is the unit vector pointing toward the angle ð; Þ, and k 0 ¼ ð! c þ !Þ=c is the usual propagation constant near a center frequency of ! c . On the other hand, the active gain G m ð!Þ captures all linear transceiver effects [60]. 3 The ultimate goal of the DBF process is to digitally remove nonideal aspects of G m and F m in order to form P beams upon summation of the resulting element-level signals, each with prescribed pattern characteristics (pointing angle, sidelobe level, null angle, etc.). Mathematically, this can be expressed for the pth beam as
div.formula: Y p ð!Þ ¼ X M m¼1 H m;p ð!ÞX m ð!Þ(3)
div.p: where H m;p ð!Þ is the frequency-domain equivalent of the DBF processing on the mth element for the pth beam. This DBF process is typically implemented in a manner that is equivalent to a finite impulse response (FIR) form 4 as
div.formula: y p ½n ¼ X M m¼1 X KÀ1 k¼0 a m;p ½kx m ½n À k (4)
div.p: where x m ½n is the complex baseband equivalent sampled data on the mth element and a m;p ½k are the equivalent digital weights applied for beam p along time ðkÞ and space ðmÞ.
There are three operations involved in guiding practical DBF implementation details:

• the actual DBF processing that results in the H m;p X m products and subsequent aggregation through (4) (Section II-B); • explicit estimation of F m and G m errors (deviations from ideal values) through calibration/ alignment processes, and the use of this information to derive the fixed portions of a m;p ½k (Section IV); • implicit removal of subsequent residual errors through ADBF, the adaptive determination of N effective DOF weights within the a m;p ½k to ultimately form the realized H m;p (Section III). These three operations are critically interrelated and are very system and application dependent. What follows is a general description of the resulting trade space that sets the stage for more specific discussions in the rest of the paper.

Channels G m are, in general, functions of temperature, frequency, and transceiver configuration (e.g., tunable filter settings), and errors therein can be significant in highly integrated, low-cost transceivers. Digital equalization, the correction of G m with H m;p , is very important when wideband interference suppression is to be performed with a limited number of DOF with ADBF; this is exemplified by the example in Section V. Overall waveform quality must also be considered for many applications [62].

Errors in F m can be less straightforward. For the large-array approximation in (2), these consist of phase deviations due to element location errors or slight variations in F 0 due to manufacturing issues. For smaller arrays, variations in mutual coupling environments among the elements combine with other platform-related effects to complicate the F m patterns. For single-mode (minimum scattering [64], [65]) antennas, the F m can be described fully with simple matrix-based equations that capture mutual coupling effects through linear combinations of patterns like (2) for each digital element. These can in turn be corrected with matrix-based processing to derive a m;p [63]. More sophisticated models are required for complex elements and for conformal arrays [66]- [68]. The important underlying fact is that these small-array effects generally require that element-level patterns be measured/known in order to inform accurate pattern synthesis as part of the calibration process [69], especially for wide bandwidths. An example of the need for-and efficacy of-these smallarray techniques is shown in Fig. 3, which demonstrates that a basic calibration that assumes the accuracy of ( 2) is insufficient to correct for mutual coupling effects in this particular array.

Fundamentally, errors in the correction for these channel and pattern effects will map to limits in beamforming performance, and thus there is inherently a relationship between beamforming, adaptation, and calibration in pursuit of the overall DBF goal of producing quality beams. This is illustrated further by highlevel examples throughout the rest of the paper.

As a basic example, consider a planar array where (2) holds perfectly. Basic calibration at broadside (wherever ûð; Þ Á ½r m À r 0 ¼ 0 for all elements) measures the relative G m through frequency-domain analysis of the x m ½n signals from (4) upon far-field illumination by a probing signal. For a given beam p, a m;p ½k are set to effectively provide
div.formula: H m;p ð!Þ ¼ B m;p ð!Þ=G m ð!Þ, where B m;p ð!Þ
B m;p ð!Þ ¼ W m e Àjk 0 ûð p ; p ÞÁ½r m Àr 0 (5)
div.p: to scan to ð p ; p Þ. Even in this simple and nonadaptive case, there are many architectural considerations to address for practical implementation; this is the topic of the following sections.

div.head: A. Front-End Processing Considerations
div.p: There are many options for practical implementation of (4), and processing architecture choices are highly application dependent. Martinez et al. [70] give an exceptional overview of both the back-end DBF processing and data transfer or aggregation trade spaces, with examples mapped to smaller but generic and advanced multichannel arrays. These topics are briefly surveyed in this section.

Element-level DBF processing typically involves conversion of ADC samples to complex baseband (I/Q) samples for subsequent DBF stages. These signal samples may be generated in subbanded (frequency-domain) form for applications where the signal of interest can be logically channelized. Radio astronomy is one such application, where polyphase filter banks are often employed [51], [52]. The precise relationship between a m;p ½k and H m;p ð!Þ is established by such architectural choices. For example, for a direct-conversion implementation with time-domain processing like the Army DAR [32], the I/Q samples are already complex baseband; thus, one simply has DFTfa m;p ½kg ¼ H m;p ð!Þ within the Nyquist bandwidth after appropriate normalization. On the other hand, an IF-sampled system with frequency-domain processing may involve FFT-based implementation of the convolution process in (4) in addition to prior digital down-conversion and decimation. In this case, the transform from the a m;p ½k to H m;p ð!Þ involves frequency shifting and scaling as well.

Regardless of the architecture, the overall function is to impose equivalent complex baseband channels, such as (5), on each element's signal, paying careful attention to the overall frequency-dependent phase in wideband systems. This includes channel-level equalization [71], Fig. 3. Digital matrix-based mutual coupling compensation illustration using the techniques in [63] on the eight-element testbed in I/Q correction [72], [73], and removal of any static local oscillator (LO) phase offsets [18]. This is in addition to the amplitude tapering and phase shifting associated with (5) as well as any pattern corrections. It is more computationally efficient to perform several corrections at once, e.g., combining true time delays (TTDs) with equalization [74]. Again, implementation can be in the time or frequency domain. Additionally, all of these error-correction processes require practical calibration solutions as part of the design trade space. This design space also naturally includes physical/architectural considerations.

div.head: B. Distributed Processing and Aggregation Considerations
div.p: A unique aspect of fully digital arrays relative to other high performance computing applications is that the data sources are often tied to fixed positions on a physical array lattice. Mechanical and serviceability considerations lead to the physical segregation of the array into a number of digital front-end (DFE) modules, very much like analog subarrays. Practical DFE connectedness strategies map to physical implementations that come in a variety of forms, as summarized in Fig. 4. While some of the past examples in the Introduction show that it is practical to build smaller arrays using a centralized DBF topology [Fig. 4(c)], most larger arrays require that large amounts of data be aggregated in some way before being sent to or between a number of subsequent processing nodes. As an example, even a 64 Â 64 element array with only 100 MHz of sampling bandwidth would have on the order of 10 Tb/s of total ADC data to process into what might be only a few beams of 20 Mb/s waveform data.

Hierarchical beamformers [Fig. 4(d)] reduce the number of data streams at each level of the hierarchy, performing partial weighting and aggregation along the way. Systolic beamformers [Fig. 4(b)] are similar, but instead of aggregating data in parallel at a given "stage," data are sent serially down a link of nodes (or even elements), with partial beam data being aggregated along the way to produce outputs for subsequent processing stages. This requires that buffers of sufficient memory depth be placed along each chain. It also increases overall latency, but this can be quite manageable if the links are short. An example of such processing at the outputs of digitized subarray was reported in [75]. Virtually every digital array of moderate to large size known to the authors uses some form of hierarchical/systolic processing to form DFEs, including most of the larger examples from the Introduction.
Mathematically, the implementation of (4) would resemble
div.formula: y p ½n ¼ X Q q¼1 X LÀ1 l¼1 c q;p ½l X m2S q X RÀ1 r¼0 d m;p ½rx m ½n À r À l (6)
div.p: for one stage of hierarchical or systolic processing. Here, the S q are the elements in the qth digital subarray, which is often simply a physical DFE but need not be. The index r and the corresponding d m;p ½r represent elementlevel filtering (amplitude and phase manipulation) for the mth element in S q , which may vary with beam number p. Similarly, the index l and the corresponding c q;p ½l represent filtering of the qth digital subarray output for beam p. The processing above has a frequency domain equivalent in the form of
div.formula: Y p ð!Þ ¼ X Q q¼1 C q;p ð!Þ X m2S q D m;p ð!ÞX m ð!Þ(7)
div.p: which maps back to the effective H m;p ð!Þ in (3). This particular "one-stage" architecture is popular because it essentially replicates the analog beamforming performed by a digitized subarray (Fig. 1), but in an inherently flexible way [32], [76]. Many systems use the D m;p for fixed channel equalization and subarray steering, followed by ADBF with the C q;p acting as the DOF; this is discussed more in the next section.

A common nonadaptive use of this architecture is TTD beamforming over wide bandwidths, where the frequency-dependent phase of k 0 in (5) is corrected. This is performed at the element level in smaller or extremely wideband digital [77] or analog [78], [79] arrays to prevent beam smearing. In larger or moderate-bandwidth arrays, TTD can be implemented on the digital subarray (DFE) outputs, just like on equivalent digitized subarray (analog) architectures. In ( 6) and ( 7), R ¼ 1 and d m;p ¼ D m;p ð0Þ ¼ B m;p ð0Þ (a phase shift at an RF of ! c ), and C q;p ð!Þ or c q;p ½l is set to provide a scan angle-dependent delay to the phase center of the qth subarray for the pth beam. When TTD is combined with the formation of multiple beams, one must carefully trade time versus frequency domain implementation costs [53]. Either way, this provides a significant reduction in the overall processing complexity over element-level TTD (on the order of Q=M) that is traded against frequency-dependent grating lobes [4].

Importantly, and unlike analog arrays, with hierarchical/systolic beamforming the number of beams can be traded against the signal bandwidth in the digital domain, with a fixed overall "beam-bandwidth" product remaining roughly constant at every point in the frontend processing chain. For multitier hierarchies, the interconnection costs scale with the logarithm of the number of elements M, while data and front-end processing scales roughly linearly with M. Both scale with the overall system bandwidth. These types of considerations guide the design of any front-end DBF architecture within the overall trade space of calibration, beamforming, and adaptation.

div.head: C. Novel Concepts for Future DBF Back-End Interconnections
div.p: While hierarchical and systolic topologies primarily complement front-end processing needs, back-end signal processing (including ADBF processing) is commonly performed on a centralized architecture [Fig. 4(c)]. This produces "bottlenecks" in that all data support required for such processes must ultimately arrive at a single location. For ADBF, this fundamentally requires independent samples from all DOF sources prior to processing.

Because parallel processing is a fundamental mechanism by which modern high-performance computing systems continue to improve, new concepts are needed for digital-array-specific applications to enable parallelization of both fixed and adaptive processing while maximally utilizing the data links for any required "all-to-all" communication between distributed processing nodes. Given this, mesh-based topologies [Fig. 4(e)] are future alternatives to centralized approaches to the final stages of beamforming. What is needed are architectures that distribute parallelizable back-end processing tasks between processing nodes or DFEs in Fig. 4. Two such future concepts for meshbased beamforming are summarized in Fig. 5.

A regular 2-D mesh network like the one shown in Fig. 4 will have edge DFEs or processing nodes with fewer connections than those in the middle. A more optimal configuration would interconnect the top to bottom and left to right, forming a torus. One way to implement such connections without long physical links is to use a functionally equivalent folded torus. A simple illustrative 4 Â 4 example is shown on the left of Fig. 5 [76]. This interconnection strategy distributes the roughly uniform traffic needed for both fixed and adaptive beamforming [80], provides means of redundancy for bypassing any nonfunctioning DFEs, and maintains a mean path length between nodes that scales better than linearly, with ffiffiffi ffi Q p for Q nodes.

A second future interconnection concept is that of spanning trees, exemplified in Fig. 5 for a simple 3 Â 3 mesh configuration. The assumption is that back-end fixed or adaptive signal processing is to be equally distributed among nodes in order to implement and/or expand upon the second summation stage of (7). This configuration allows for the maximum number of simultaneous beams to be processed for a given link bandwidth between nodes or, equivalently, to evenly distribute data from all DOF sources to a number of fixed processing nodes [76]. In the figure, nine such "trees" are mapped with only six interconnections between each node. For a given maximum link bandwidth between physical nodes, this configuration provides a maximally flexible solution. Even with optimal front-end processing and data distribution architectures, the advent of fully digital arrays provides a number of challenges and opportunities for adaptive processing of these data. This is explored at a high level in Section III.

div.head: III. ADAPTIVE BEAMFORMING CONCEPTS
div.p: Adaptive beamforming represents a mature set of array signal processing techniques that is primarily used to reduce the impact of interference or clutter on the system in the presence of uncorrected G m and/or F m errors from Section II. It is also generally required when interference directions are unknown. Adaptive techniques are generally more computationally expensive than traditional, fixed-weight beamformers and therefore operate by adaptively combining a limited number of overall array DOFs. The manner in which these combining weights are determined and the order in which the processing and aggregation take place are all part of a broad trade space that considers the application's requirements as well as practical technology limitations. After a general overview of the standard algorithms and processes, this section presents the rough complexities of a few representative ADBF schemes and describes a new technique based on the matrix inversion lemma (MIL) that can help reduce the underlying complexity in some cases.

div.head: A. ADBF Overview and Complexity
div.p: As indicated in Section II, ADBF can be generalized as processing N d DOF within the a m;p ½k to achieve the overall DBF goals [9], [10]. In fully digital arrays, this usually takes a form similar to ( 6) and ( 7), with c q;p ½l generically representing the adaptive weights for the pth beam on the qth digital subarray output sum after fixed processing with the equivalent d m;p ½r within each digital subarray. The DOFs may also operate on frequencydomain data, different pulses (e.g., STAP [81]), or Doppler bins as well.

While it is common to derive DOFs from the outputs of fixed, digitized subarrays, a unique aspect of digital arrays is that element-level adaptation is possible, with Q ¼ M. Unlike analog arrays, digital arrays can in principle also allow for remapping of digital subarrays to best suit a given application. Ultimately, it is the nature of expected interference that drives DOF choices from a subset of practical subarray configurations. In general, the more DOF one uses, the more data support is needed for ADBF. However, sidelobe performance and signal-tonoise ratio losses improve. The work in [14] provides an excellent overview of this trade space for digital arrays, concluding that element-level ADBF may not be necessary or even practical, but that performance does improve with a large number (hundreds) of DOF in large arrays.

If implementing ADBF on a distributed processing architecture like those suggested in Fig. 5, one must consider that it requires "all-to-all" communication between nodes; this may lead to "bottlenecks." One must, of course, also consider the overall computational complexity. In this section, this is presented at a high level in terms of floating point operations (FLOPs), and complex signals are assumed throughout.

Most adaptive beamforming algorithms can be generalized to the following steps to process N c signals (for N d ¼ N c À 1 DOF) using N s independent data support samples from these signals: 1) estimation of the signal covariance matrix
div.formula: S x ¼ 1 N s X N s i¼1 x i x H i (8)
div.p: where x i is the ith N s Â 1 column vector of training or support data; 2) matrix inversion of this covariance matrix; 3) calculation of adaptive weights w ¼ S À1 x w 0 based on a nominal steering vector w 0 ; and 4) application of the weights to each of the incoming data samples x as y ¼ w H x. There may also be signal conditioning (e.g., FFTs) required before or after this processing if time domain processing is not used. Step 1) by itself takes
div.formula: N 1 ðN c ; N s Þ % 8N 2 c N s þ 2N 2 c FLOPs. Step 2) takes N 2 ðN c Þ % N 3
div.p: c FLOPs to get to row-reduced form, followed by N 3 ðN c Þ % 3N c ðN c À 1Þ FLOPs for each beam in 3) and finally 4)

c FLOPs for each beamdata point product at the output. Typically, however, a QR decomposition and back-substitution is used to execute steps 1)-3) for efficiency and numerical stability reasons [70], requiring
div.formula: N QR ðN c ; N s ; PÞ % 8N 2 c ðN s À N c =3Þ þ 4PN 2
div.p: c FLOPs in total for P output beams. These are summarized in Table 1 for reference; more details are available in [70].

Traditionally, a narrowband ADBF uses N ch digital channels and potentially N p pulses from each channel to form the N c signals to be adaptively combined. For example, STAP uses multiple pulses from multiple channels to adaptively form output beams in P different directions. For wideband applications, the effective G m ð!ÞF m ð!; ; Þ products from (1) may vary significantly over the signal bandwidth. Without precise calibration and front-end processing to address such variations, ADBF would require more DOF to produce wideband nulls at the interference locations. These extra DOFs could come from N t taps in a filter [e.g., the K taps in (4)], weighting different time delays of each channel such that N c ¼ N t N ch . ADBF would then produce output time samples for P beams. Section V describes an example of this. For many such applications, it is common to instead first perform an FFT on channel data to form N f frequency bins, separating the wideband ADBF process into N f narrowband ones that are executed in parallel. The FFTs require N 5 ðN ch ; N f Þ ¼ 5N ch N f log 2 N f FLOPs, which scales well with N f . This may form P separate beams as well, with N f being roughly equivalent to N t above. In all cases, typically N s ¼ 2N d to 5N d , with additional samples (diagonal loading) used to ensure stability. This amount of statistically independent data sample support can become impractical for a large number of DOFs and/or frequency bins.

div.head: B. MIL and Applications
div.p: The computationally expensive OðN 3 Þ QR decomposition step must be performed after all the training data are received. If the number of DOFs increases, it becomes beneficial to mitigate the computational cost of the inversion. One potential technique for this complexity reduction is the application of the MIL to update previous inverse covariance estimates as data arrives [82].

If S x ðiÞ is defined to be the estimate of the covariance matrix using the first i samples, then the covariance estimate ( 8) can be calculated recursively with an update constant k s as S x ðiÞ¼ S x ði À1Þþð1=k
div.formula: s Þx i x H i . As mentioned, the MIL ðA þ UCVÞ À1 ¼ A À1 À A À1 UðC þ VA À1 UÞ À1 VA À1
div.p: can ease the computational burden of covariance matrix inverse calculation. An inverse of the estimate of the covariance matrix can be updated by setting the variables from the MIL to
div.formula: A ¼ S x ði À 1Þ, U ¼ ð1= ffiffiffi ffi k s p Þx i , C ¼ I, and V ¼ ð1= ffiffiffiffi k s p
div.p: Þx H i and inserting into the equation as shown

div.head: S À1
div.p: x ðiÞ ¼ S À1 x ði À 1Þ À
div.formula: S À1 x ði À 1Þx i x H i S À1 x ði À 1Þ k s þ x H i S À1 x ði À 1Þx i :(9)
div.p: The efficacy of this approach has been confirmed using data from the National Weather Radar Testbed (NWRT) phased array radar, a SPY-1A repurposed for weather surveillance. Meteorological data were collected using the NWRT's main channel and sidelobe canceler channels, and the MIL-based algorithm was shown to produce virtually identical results to traditional techniques in adaptively removing clutter [83]. Its primary advantage is in the efficiency of ( 9), with a beam weight computational complexity as shown in Table 1 for each iteration as new data come in. It is being explored for future digital array weather radar applications because it would enable ADBF with a large number of digital DOF, as it scales fundamentally N 2 c instead of N 3 c . High DOF counts would lead to minimization of peak sidelobe levels [14] while simultaneously minimizing ground clutter beyond nominal sidelobe levels. Its primary disadvantage is that the covariance estimates are slow to change to dynamic clutter/interference requirements, and thus it is not appropriate for all applications. This is yet another example of the application dependence of overall DBF trade spaces.

div.head: IV. CALIBRATION OF DIGITAL ARRAYS
div.p: Most phased array systems require a calibration process for optimum performance. While the details vary, the general goal is to ensure that each element's frequencydependent amplitudes and phases are set correctly in order to achieve the desired beam pattern(s). As indicated in Section II, this ultimately consists of measurement-based estimation of F m and G m in (1) to derive optimal values of the fixed (nonadaptive) DBF weights making up the effective a m;p ½k in ( 4). What follows is a summary of the survey in [84] that highlights practical issues for digital array calibration, followed by updates that highlight more recent results and applications derived from the advanced mutual coupling algorithms presented therein.

div.head: A. General Considerations and Nomenclature
div.p: For all types of arrays, an important general distinction is whether a given calibration routine is part of the initial characterization of a new system (i.e., initial calibration), or if it is meant to operate when the system is in an operational state (i.e., in situ calibration). Initial calibration based on far-field measurements in an anechoic chamber or outdoors requires a spacing between the array and the test antenna on the order of 2D 2 = to 8D 2 = for an array of maximum dimension D, depending on the techniques used [10]; this can often be prohibitive. Fortunately, near-field scanning has reached a point where it is widely considered to be a mature process [10], [85]. Near-field probe scans allow for the calculation of far-field and "back-projected" near-field patterns. This a powerful tool for overall array diagnostics, especially for large arrays. Once the array has been fielded, in situ calibration often becomes critical in maintaining performance over temperature and time. For example, the German Aerospace Center predicts that their spacebased DBF imaging systems will require almost continuous amplitude and phase corrections [86].

Another important distinction is whether a given calibration technique makes use of internal or external calibration equipment; see Fig. 6. External processes (item 1) use equipment that is not intended to be fielded along with the array, e.g., anechoic chambers. Internal calibration (items 2-4, discussed in Section IV-C) refers to processes that utilize the array hardware itself or any dedicated calibration equipment that is fielded along with the array.

div.head: B. Practical Digital Array Calibration Considerations
div.p: There are important practical challenges that complicate these processes in digital arrays, particularly during initial calibration.

• While analog arrays can often be simply measured using a network analyzer (or equivalent "RF-to-RF" electronics), digital transceiver-based arrays require that any external equipment be phase locked to provide a true "RF-to-digital" interface. This typically involves careful reference clock distribution or the use of dedicated auxiliary transceiver channels from the native digital array. • A typical hierarchical/systolic DBF may not be able to pass element-level data to a central processor in real time. Thus, for calibration it is common to buffer and then stream these data to a central calibration processor. This should be considered early in the design process. • Multiple LOs may be used to drive the digital transceivers to provide improvements in phase noise [87] and array flexibility. These LOs may require phase synchronization during calibration [84]. Similarly, digital sample clock synchronization must be ensured through proper design; small, residual offsets can be compensated with wideband calibration using TTD [77]. At the same time, all calibration routines performed on fully digital arrays have potential calibration advantages relative to analog arrays because the waveform interfaces are digital.

• Digital arrays have mathematical precision limited by processing (e.g., 16-b integer math), not analog phase shifting and/or time delay resolution (e.g., 6 b). Though such high element-level accuracy is not usually required for large arrays where random errors are more tolerable, this may be necessary for smaller arrays and for general subarray-level processing. • Analog arrays may need to be calibrated/ measured over a significant subset of their phase/ amplitude states because of attenuation-dependent phase shifts, phase shift-dependent amplitude shifts, etc. [88]. Digital domain signal manipulation obviates this need on Rx and may simplify the treatment of Tx electronic control nonlinearities (such as amplifier compression). • Analog arrays generally only allow for direct measurement of combined signals on either Tx or Rx.

To measure individual elements, one must switch elements on and off or use phase toggling techniques; see [89]- [91] for examples and [84] for details. Digital arrays usually allow for direct measurement of element-level signals on Rx, and can implement phase toggling techniques with high precision on Tx. In the midst of these low-level issues, one must consider the higher level trend of digital arrays moving from test racks with cabled antennas to operational platforms with integrated, low-cost transceiver electronics. With this trend comes the risk of increased static and time/ temperature-dependent errors in the active gains G m (Section II) [92]. Given the overall goal described at the top of this section, it is clear that robust calibration processes are themselves an enabling technology for digital arrays in some applications. There are important additional digital array benefits that help with these. First, digital arrays naturally provide more processing DOF for equalization/TTD than their analog counterparts, generalizing to (4) or ( 6) and (7). With enough processing, error correction is limited only by stability of the electronics and calibration accuracies. Second, there are a number of emerging in situ calibration techniques to maintain performance over time that are well suited for digital arrays. This is the topic of Section IV-C.

div.head: C. In Situ Calibration and Mutual-Coupling-Based Techniques
div.p: It is increasingly common to include dedicated internal calibration hardware on fielded phased arrays to support calibration, as depicted in Fig. 6. The discussion that follows here focuses on emerging techniques that seek to make maximal use of element-level digitization to overcome calibration challenges using these techniques.

A high-quality, embedded calibration network near the array face could source or receive nearly identical signal levels at each element, as depicted as item 2 in Fig. 6. Early examples include series feed microstrip lines [27], [93]. The TerraSAR-X satellite uses embedded coupling to each element for in situ calibration [94], maintaining $0.2 dB and $2 overall element-level accuracy [95]. Both of the digital arrays in [30] and [31] used coupled injection for receive-only in situ calibration. These types of networks have been recently incorporated into single-chip arrays as well [96], and remain common in general.

While these embedded networks are effective for smaller arrays on a single module or circuit board, it may be difficult to realize error-free RF signal distribution over a large array. An alternative mechanism makes use of probe antennas in the near field of the array to monitor changes to array behavior (item 3). Examples include the fixed probe in [97], or built-in near-field scanners for initial and in situ calibration [98]. The relative merits of these techniques were detailed in [84].

The ideal digital array calibration mechanism would use the inherent hardware available within the array, scale naturally to large arrays, and provide both in situ and initial calibration. This suggests the use of the inherent mutual coupling between antenna elements (item 4 in Fig. 6) as feedback paths to replace the aforementioned probe antennas with other array elements. Digital arrays that have element-level transceivers naturally support this. Starting in the late 1980s, digital array testbeds were used to explore initial calibration. Under the largearray approximation of (2), one also has that pairs of elements sharing the same geometrical separation should have identical mutual coupling [99], [100]. By examining pairwise coupling comparisons across the array, transceiver error correction and even pattern prediction were demonstrated. The same narrowband techniques were used in [101] and [102] a decade later.

Motivated by these examples, the technique was recently extended to focus on precise in situ calibration on smaller systems where the large-array approximation is invalid. The resulting algorithm, summarized here from [72], [84], and [103], seeks to ensure that temperatureand system-induced errors in these highly integrated arrays can be corrected. If a group of Tx elements indexed by n transmit separately to a separate group of Rx elements indexed by m, one can build a matrix Kð!Þ whose entries K m;n ð!Þ contain the measured complex couplings as seen through the digital transceivers. Subsequent identical measurements, forming the matrix K 0 ð!Þ, will reflect changes to the active transmit and receive channels, denoted as G T n ð!Þ and G R m ð!Þ, respectively. The singular value decomposition (SVD) of the matrix whose ðm; nÞth entry is K 0 m;n ð!Þ=K m;n ð!Þ holds the errors in G R m ð!Þ and G T n ð!Þ in its left and right dominant singular vectors, respectively, to within an overall complex constant. These are then digitally corrected. The Army DAR example shown in Fig. 7 demonstrated that narrowband errors can be self-corrected through this basic process. Errors were kept to within a few degrees and tenths of a decibel despite large temperature-induced errors.

Changes to antenna S-parameters and the nearby electromagnetic environment will also change the effective couplings K 0 ð!Þ, either for mutual-coupling-or probe-based techniques. The work in [84] and [103] showed that the sum of the nondominant singular values, denoted as , tended to track errors induced by such changes, either random or localized (e.g., through disconnecting elements). Fig. 8(a) shows an example of versus the associated complex root mean square (RMS) element errors in G m resulting from simulated errors being added to the S-parameters of the 9 Â 9 array from [104]. By setting a threshold on for tolerable G m errors, these techniques can provide robustness against temporary environmental effects, such as the flexing of a radome in the wind [105].

These techniques are not without limitations. Receiver linearity must be considered when transmitting and receiving on nearby elements. Early implementations like the one in Fig. 7 were also limited by awkwardness in grouping the Tx and Rx elements to cover the entire array. The large-array initial calibration routine highlighted above was recently significantly improved by the work in [106]. This in turn inspired improvements to the in situ routine to track both high-power and lowpower sets of couplings with generalized, array-level coupling matrices that together help overcome these limitations. These new techniques employ the logarithm of coupling ratios, rather than the ratios themselves, and are currently being applied to the conformal array in [107]. Similar algorithms have emerged for performing calibration based on reflections from nearby targets [108], single-Tx versions of these algorithms for larger Rx arrays [109], MIMO radar returns to estimate phase errors on Tx [110], and even calibration based entirely on clutter returns [111].

Both the initial and in situ mutual coupling techniques were extended to wide bandwidths in [103]. Fig. 8(b) shows an example of the initial estimation of a small simulated channel imperfection using this wideband extension of [106]. Application of the algorithm resulted in G m ð!Þ being estimated to within 1% (0.6 or 0.1 dB) RMS of its nominal value for the element shown. This study showed similar estimation errors on other elements and for larger intrinsic channel imperfections. In a real-time system, such estimators inform the effective H m;p ð!Þ corrections in (3). The final section exemplifies the type of processing reductions that may become possible as these digital array calibration mechanisms continue to mature in applicability and accuracy.

div.head: V. WIDEBAND ADAPTIVE BEAMFORMING AND CALIBRATION TRADEOFF EXAMPLE
div.p: The prospect of element-level digital equalization and coupling correction through advanced calibration could, in principle, lead to new modes of operation that reduce the inherent need for adaptivity. Many of the citations at the end of Section IV are attempting to do just that. For the practical STAP application in [112], it was shown that calibration leads to simplified adaptive processing through a priori knowledge of the underlying signal covariance that takes errors into account. These approaches reduce the need for many independent data samples to support large-DOF ADBF. This is important because sample independence is often limited when discrete clutter and signal artifacts are present. In general, the extent to which calibration and initial measurements can mitigate the pattern and transceiver effects described in Section II may be traded against the required complexity of ADBF. Instead of exploring this high-level concept in a comprehensive manner, the following demonstrates through a simplified but wideband example how the need for adaptive processing in some cases could be minimized through precise array calibration.

div.head: A. Overall Scenario and Adaptive Approach
div.p: Consider a situation where one wants to steer a M ¼ 16 element array in a desired direction d (e.g., þ30 from broadside) while placing a null in another direction n (e.g., À45 ) to minimize clutter or interference over a broad bandwidth. To maintain precise beam control versus frequency, each channel has a K ¼ 32-tap FIR filter for TTD and equalization. This fast space-time processing could be performed with wideband ADBF as described in Section III-A to maintain a precise null in the presence of calibration errors in correcting for errors in G m and F m of Section II. For the numbers here, the resulting complexity for ADBF weight calculations would be fairly high-on the order of $4 GFLOPs-while scaling roughly with ðMKÞ 3 based on Table 1. A comparable FFT-based frequency-domain approach would require $4 MFLOPs in this case, still scaling roughly with M 3 K for larger M while requiring similar data support.

A more efficient option would be to use beam-space processing. First, consider a TTD-processed beam steered in the desired direction d using the techniques of [74] and [77] to derive the 32-tap FIR filter weights, taking equalization and coupling compensation into account as described in Section II. Denote the response of the resulting beam when scanning to d as F d ð!; ; d Þ, which varies with frequency ! and angle . A second beam could, in parallel, be processed to form a beam peak in a known desired null direction n , resulting in a response of F u ð!; ; n Þ. One could then form the following composite beam:
div.formula: F t ð!; ; d ; n Þ ¼ F d ð!; ; d Þ À H r ð!ÞF u ð!; ; n Þ (10) where H r ð!Þ ¼ F d ð!; n ; d Þ=F u ð!; n ; n Þ
div.p: is the ratio of the two aforementioned beams evaluated at the null angle n . This response would be approximated through filtering of the F u data stream with an N r -tap digital filter. This composite beam F t achieves the simultaneous beam pointing/null steering goal outlined above, and is effectively a wideband form of a generalized sidelobe canceler [14]. This ideal processing, of course, requires that the response H r be precisely known, and that N r be sufficiently large. It is possible to adaptively estimate the N r filter taps based on data from the F u and F d data streams, requiring a complexity of $ 40N 3 r FLOPs based on arguments surrounding Table 1. For N r ¼ 16, this evaluates to a much more manageable $150 KFLOPs for each adaptation. This type of processing could be extended to adaptively accommodate more than one discrete interference source with the addition of N n other filters and null-steered beams, so long as the increased number of adapted beams and resulting DOF scaling is supported by sufficient processing resources. Importantly, it must also be supported by increasing amounts of truly independent data samples, which are not always available [112].

div.head: B. Calibration-Based Approach and Results
div.p: For cases where interference angles are truly discrete and relatively stationary, a more ideal solution would implement (10) using deterministic (fixed) weights, eliminating ADBF altogether. This would require precise calibration to stabilize any changes to the active channels such that previous and precise knowledge of the G m and F m values from Section II can be trusted in forming and predicting the main and null-steered beam pattern.

For reference, the calibration computational complexity corresponding to this scenario is as little as $75 KFLOPs using the algorithms in [103], including FFTs, matrix manipulations, and updates to channel equalizations. Scaling with M would lie between M 2 K and M 3 K, depending on how many transmit elements are included for training, and does not scale with the number of nulls N n because weights are fixed as a function of the angles n and d . Changes to these angles only require on the order of 5N r N n FLOPs to update the H r based on stored initial manifold information from careful but one-time (initial) calibration.

A concrete example of this fixed processing is shown in Fig. 9, using the numbers above in a simulated system with a 100% fractional bandwidth. The top left plot shows the total response F t from (10) as a function of angle as well as normalized complex baseband frequency != for the 16-element array. The beam steers towards d ¼ 30 at all frequencies while providing a deep (70 dBc) null at n ¼ À45 with N r ¼ 16 taps implementing a perfectly calibrated H r ð!Þ.

To explore the limits of this technique relative to calibration accuracy, errors were added to the G m ð!Þ without correction of the H r filter. Overall complex gain errors of (%) RMS at ! ¼ 0 were cascaded with fractional time delay errors and gain slope errors which, when normalized to one unit delay and 100%, respectively, also had RMS values of . Overall, this provides a convenient, overall calibration error scaling factor. The top right figure shows the resulting overall F t pattern for ¼ 3.3%, and the bottom plot shows the value of F t at n versus ! for several values of . With the $1.0% RMS errors like those in Figs. 7 and8, a respectable $45-dB null would be produced for this small array under realistic calibration limitations. At the center frequency, where the gain slope and time delay errors are zero, the theoretical null level can be readily shown to be on the order of 10 log 10 þ 10 log 10 M dB [4]. For the error levels in the figure, this corresponds to 72, 62, 52, 42, and 32 dB, respectively; the results are clearly very close to this. Such a rule of thumb is useful in mapping array-level performance to the stability of individual channels in these arrays, in turn helping to guide the extent to which a given algorithm may rely on calibration accuracy to drive down the complexity of more advanced processing functions.

This example has shown that sufficient calibration can provide wideband interference suppression with a sufficiently stationary interference direction. Like the MIL algorithm in Section III-B, this has natural limits in dynamic and high-rank interference scenarios. Some form of direction of arrival estimation [113] would be needed if the interference direction changes, or the null(s) could be steered iteratively until interference is minimized. Either way, the data support and processing requirements could be substantially reduced over that of traditional ADBF for certain applications. This example simply serves to illustrate how the calibration and data

div.head: VI. CONCLUSION
div.p: Digital phased array technology promises to deliver new levels of performance and multifunctionality in future radar and communication systems. The move to arrays with digitization at the element level comes with a number of practical risks associated with signal processing, data management, and the complexity of increasingly integrated electronics. The ultimate goal for future systems will be to leverage the opportunities provided by element-level digitization to mitigate errors and performance limitations associated with the use of lower cost transceiver hardware while providing a fundamentally scalable and flexible digital beamforming architecture. This broad survey of the engineering trade spaces surrounding these systems has highlighted a number of specific challenges and opportunities, ultimately suggesting that advanced calibration and networking schemes should seek to make maximal use of the inherent flexibility in these digital architectures to enhance system-level performance through novel calibration and digital beamforming techniques. h
